item.title: Michael Kroger quits as Victorian Liberal Party president after election drubbing - ABC News
item.description:
Michael Kroger quits as Victorian Liberal Party president after election drubbing  ABC News

Victorian Liberal Party president Michael Kroger has quit following the party's disastrous result in last week's state election.

Liberals stall on gender at state election as Labor closes in on 50 per cent women  The Age

item.title: Victorian Liberals to shut down injecting room in a week if elected - The Age
item.description:
Victorian Liberals to shut down injecting room in a week if elected  The Age

The opposition will shut down the state's only medically supervised drug injecting room within a week if voted into government in this Saturday's state election.

item.title: Liberal Party will fight order to dump how-to-vote cards - The Age
item.description:
Liberal Party will fight order to dump how-to-vote cards  The Age

The Liberal Party will fight a legal order to dump batches of statewide how-to-vote cards after Victoria's civil tribunal ruled they should be deregistered.

item.title: Liberal Party backs independent candidate who says homosexuals can be cured - The Age
item.description:
Liberal Party backs independent candidate who says homosexuals can be cured  The Age

The Liberal Party has thrown its support behind a former mental health counsellor who promoted gay conversion therapy and said homosexuals can be cured.

item.title: New Lib leader claims the centre - The Australian
item.description:
New Lib leader claims the centre  The Australian

Victoria’s new Liberal leader has vowed to function as a centrist who is mindful of climate change but does not want to get overwhelmed by dysfunctional internal analysis. Michael O’Brien, 47, is a former senior adviser to federal treasurer Peter Costello, and was elevated to the leadership yesterday after the November 24 rout led to Matthew Guy’s resignation. Mr O’Brien will implement an overhaul of the party just months from a federal election and try to unite depleted forces without a permanent party president. Rural MP Cindy McLeish was elected his deputy, veteran frontbencher David Dav...

item.title: Victorian Liberal women push for quotas since 'we do have 50 per cent females in our communities' - ABC News
item.description:
Victorian Liberal women push for quotas since 'we do have 50 per cent females in our communities'  ABC News

By Joseph Dunstan Victorian Liberal women are urging the party to learn from its crushing state election defeat and introduce quotas to support the elevation of more female MPs into the parliament. Liberal leader Matthew Guy quit last week and the party's Victorian branch president, Michael Kroger, resigned on Friday night in the wake of an election result that is likely to hand Labor at least 54 seats in the 88-seat Lower House. Eight Liberal women and 22 Liberal men were likely to be safely elected from across the Lower and Upper Houses on Sunday afternoon, with Liberal women in the seats...

item.title: Greens declare 'historic' win over Labor in Brunswick - ABC News
item.description:
Greens declare 'historic' win over Labor in Brunswick  ABC News

By Joseph Dunstan The Victorian Greens have claimed victory in the inner-Melbourne seat of Brunswick after last weekend's state election, stealing the electorate from Labor for the first time in history. In a 2:00pm update on the Victorian Electoral Commission (VEC) website, Greens candidate Tim Read had gained a 514-vote lead over his Labor opponent Cindy O'Connor. This morning, Dr Read took to Facebook to declare victory, writing "for the first time, Brunswick has gone Green". "Since 1904 this seat was held by Labor, so this is historic. A few more postal votes were counted this morning, ...

item.title: Michael Kroger quits as Victorian Liberal Party president | ABC News - ABC News
item.description:
Michael Kroger quits as Victorian Liberal Party president | ABC News  ABC News

Victorian Liberal Party president Michael Kroger has quit following the party's disastrous result in last week's state election, the ABC understands. Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-11-30/michael-kroger-victorian-liberal-party-president-resigns/10573382 For more from ABC News, click here: http://www.abc.net.au/news/ Follow us on Twitter: http://twitter.com/abcnews Like us on Facebook: http://facebook.com/abcnews.au Subscribe to us on YouTube: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Follow us on Instagram: http://instagram.com/abcnews_au

item.title: Guy quits as Victorian Opposition Leader after election disaster - ABC News
item.description:
Guy quits as Victorian Opposition Leader after election disaster  ABC News

By state political reporter Richard Willingham and staff Victoria's defeated Opposition Leader Matthew Guy has stood down from the Liberal Party leadership in the wake of Saturday's electoral rout. In a brief statement, Mr Guy expressed his "deep appreciation" for the support and unity of his Liberal colleagues throughout his leadership. Mr Guy's resignation was widely expected by his colleagues after the Liberals saw a swing of about 6 per cent swing against them. Much of the criticism of the electoral disaster was initially directed at party president Michael Kroger, but there was also cr...

item.title: The big lesson from the Victorian election: get things done if you want to win - The Guardian
item.description:
The big lesson from the Victorian election: get things done if you want to win  The Guardian

After every state election, as soon as the result is known, the next story is what the federal implications might be. Usually, there are none. Australians routinely vote differently in state and federal elections, smart enough to differentiate their functions and sometimes favouring one party at the state level and another at the federal. We’ve known for months if not years that the federal government is headed for a drubbing, bar an extraordinary comeback, and yet Tasmanians and South Australians elected Liberal state governments in March, at the same time as Newspoll had Labor ahead feder...

item.title: 'Unelectable': Liberal candidate delivers scathing critique of Matthew Guy's campaign - ABC News
item.description:
'Unelectable': Liberal candidate delivers scathing critique of Matthew Guy's campaign  ABC News

By state political reporter Richard Willingham Defeated Liberal leader Matthew Guy was "unelectable," with traditional Liberal voters turning away from the party in droves over policy, the unsuccessful Liberal candidate for Albert Park has declared. In a savage post-mortem of the party's crushing election loss, Andrew Bond wrote that his community never trusted Mr Guy, and that the party was in dire straits at both state and federal levels. "The most often-heard phrase in the last month whilst doorknocking and standing on pre-poll was, 'for the first time in my life I am not voting Liberal'...

item.title: Victorian Liberal leadership aspirant John Pesutto falls behind Labor in his seat - ABC News
item.description:
Victorian Liberal leadership aspirant John Pesutto falls behind Labor in his seat  ABC News

By Jean Edwards The battle for the traditionally blue-ribbon seat of Hawthorn is going down to the wire, with Victorian Liberal frontbencher and leadership contender John Pesutto trailing his Labor rival by just 47 votes. With almost 90 per cent of the vote counted by Wednesday night, Labor's John Kennedy was in the lead with 50.1 per cent of the two-party preferred vote. Mr Pesutto will contest the Liberal leadership if he survives the count, following Matthew Guy's resignation. Shadow Treasurer Michael O'Brien is understood to be consulting colleagues about making a tilt for the job. Vict...

item.title: The Liberal party must reform itself rapidly or accept its demise - The Guardian
item.description:
The Liberal party must reform itself rapidly or accept its demise  The Guardian

The Liberal party continues to operate in a parallel universe, now claiming that the Victorian election result was an aberration rather than accepting that it is completely out of touch with the Australian community. The “base” its leaders are talking to is actually their membership base, which they have failed, rather than their voting base, which they have ignored. The Liberal executive and Liberal parliamentary members don’t seem to respect their membership base, who are mostly well-meaning people. They are not bringing them along with the community. Do they think that a membership base ...

item.title: Why a second wipe-out is looming for the Liberals - The Advertiser
item.description:
Why a second wipe-out is looming for the Liberals  The Advertiser

Then replay Labor Premier Daniel Andrews’s victory speech on Saturday — the part of it that explains exactly why the Liberals are dying. MORE ANDREW BOLT BLOG WITH BOLT MORE STATE ELECTION NEWS “We live our values, we keep our promises, and we get things done,” growled Andrews, as scores of red-shirted volunteers cheered. Could Prime Minister Scott Morrison say one syllable of that with Andrews’ mad-dog conviction? What values do today’s Liberals even have? How many promises have Morrison’s Liberals kept? What things have they got done? Labor will again form a 'strong, stable majority gover...

item.title: 'Something's gone horribly wrong': Liberals devastated by Victorian election loss - ABC News
item.description:
'Something's gone horribly wrong': Liberals devastated by Victorian election loss  ABC News

A senior Victorian Liberal MP is calling for a "root-and-branch review" of the party after its devastating election loss and a federal counterpart apologised over the impact Malcolm Turnbull's axing had on the result. Key points: - Senior Victorian Liberal MPs have lost their seats on a dire night for the party - Federal Treasurer Josh Frydenberg said Mr Turnbull's axing "didn't determine the outcome" - Shadow Attorney-General John Pesutto is among the Liberals who could be out of a job Labor was expected to win up to 61 seats after large swings in Melbourne's east. Among the Liberal MPs at...

item.title: This man was told he'd lost his job on live TV - ABC News
item.description:
This man was told he'd lost his job on live TV  ABC News

A Victorian Liberal frontbencher was told he had lost his traditionally blue-ribbon seat on live television, as Labor swept to victory in an unanticipated landslide. Shadow Attorney-General John Pesutto was praised for his gracious response as he went through the excruciating experience of hearing he had lost his seat while on air. Mr Pesutto was on the ABC TV panel as the Coalition's shocking results rolled in, and the huge swings to Labor were replicated in his blue-chip seat of Hawthorn. "You get a short time on the stage in politics," he said. "To the people of Hawthorn, I'm very gratef...

item.title: Analysis: Victorian election disaster prompts Liberal search for Matthew Guy replacement - ABC News
item.description:
Analysis: Victorian election disaster prompts Liberal search for Matthew Guy replacement  ABC News

The electoral wound inflicted on the Liberal Party by voters in Victoria is likely to get much worse before it begins to heal, with the party riven by bloodletting. Key points: - Matthew Guy is expected to stand down after the Liberals suffered a 6.1 per cent swing - John Pesutto is considered a frontrunner for the role, but is in a fight to win his seat - Michael O'Brien, the treasurer in the last Coalition government, is also a strong contender It remains unclear whether Matthew Guy will stay on as Opposition Leader after the electoral rout, with Mr Guy maintaining radio silence since the...

item.title: This man just lost his job on live TV - ABC News
item.description:
This man just lost his job on live TV  ABC News

By Nicole Mills A Victorian Liberal frontbencher has learned he lost his traditionally blue-ribbon seat on live television, as Labor swept to victory in an unanticipated landslide. Shadow Attorney-General John Pesutto has been praised for his gracious response as he went through the excruciating experience of losing his seat while on air. Mr Pesutto was on the ABC TV panel as the Coalition's shocking results rolled in, and the huge swings to Labor were replicated in his blue-chip seat of Hawthorn. "You get a short time on the stage in politics," he said. "To the people of Hawthorn, I'm very...

item.title: Lib quits over Muslim ban video - The Australian
item.description:
Lib quits over Muslim ban video  The Australian

A Victorian Liberal candidate in a key marginal seat has quit the race less than two weeks ahead of the state election, after appearing in an unauthorised video featuring the hashtag #MuslimBan. The Liberal Party’s online profile for Yan Yean candidate Meralyn Klein’s has been disabled and her Facebook page has been pulled down, after revelations she candidate appeared in a provocative video put together by the Australian Liberty Alliance. Ms Klein’s name already appears on the ballot list for Yan Yean, which is held by Labor on a thin margin 3.65 per cent and regarded by some Liberals as a...

item.title: A NSW Liberal MP says a snap federal poll would save state seats. Let the blame game begin - ABC News
item.description:
A NSW Liberal MP says a snap federal poll would save state seats. Let the blame game begin  ABC News

State Liberal MPs in Victoria and NSW are consumed with rage directed squarely at the federal Liberals for damaging the party's brand ahead of two crucial state elections. External Link: phelps tweet They argue the dysfunction coming from Canberra has done untold harm to the party among voters who put them all in the same dysfunctional basket. While there is always a debate about whether voters differentiate between state and federal politics, there is always a blurring of issues, and the Wentworth loss has sent shockwaves through not only the Federal Parliament but also the NSW and Victori...

item.title: Liberal preselection battle begins to replace Julia Banks — and it's dominated by men - ABC News
item.description:
Liberal preselection battle begins to replace Julia Banks — and it's dominated by men  ABC News

A large field of Liberal hopefuls have put their hand up to replace outspoken federal backbencher Julia Banks in the suburban Melbourne seat of Chisholm. Key points: - Ms Banks announced in August she would not contest her seat at the next federal election - Seven men and two women have nominated for Liberal Party preselection in Chisholm - Gladys Liu is understood to have the support from Victorian Liberal president Michael Kroger At a time when the Liberal Party is grappling with how to boost female representation from its ranks, only two of the nine nominees are women. Ms Banks sensation...

item.title: PM intervenes in Victorian factional row over preselection of senators - ABC News
item.description:
PM intervenes in Victorian factional row over preselection of senators  ABC News

Prime Minister Scott Morrison has used his authority to end an impasse over preselections in Victoria and ensure senators James Paterson and Jane Hume are re-endorsed. The senators had expected their preselections to be finalised 18 months ago but a conservative takeover in Victoria complicated the process and put Senator Hume's future, in particular, in doubt. The ABC understands Mr Morrison intervened almost immediately after taking over the top job and, together with his deputy and senior Victorian Liberal Josh Frydenberg, told the state's Liberal president Michael Kroger to endorse the ...
